TIPS ON PUMPING GAS (Good information)
 
 
 I don't know what you guys are paying for gasoline.... but here in California we are also paying higher, up to $3.50 per gallon. But my line of work is in petroleum for about 31 years now, so here are some tricks to get more of your money's worth for every gallon..
 
 Here at the Kinder Morgan Pipeline where I work in San Jose , CA we deliver about 4 million gallons in a 24-hour period thru the pipeline. One day is diesel the next day is jet fuel, and gasoline, regular and premium grades. We have 34-storage tanks here with a total capacity of 16,800,000 gallons.
 
 Only buy or fill up your car or truck in the early morning when the ground temperature is still cold. Remember that all service stations have their storage tanks buried below ground. The colder the ground the more dense the gasoline, when it gets warmer gasoline expands, so buying in the afternoon or in the evening....your gallon is not exactly a gallon. In the petroleum business, the specific gravity and the temperature of the gasoline, diesel and jet fuel, ethanol and other petroleum products plays an important role. A 1-degree rise in temperature is a big deal for this business. But the service stations do not have temperature compensation at the pumps.
 
 When you're filling up do not squeeze the trigger of the nozzle to a fast mode. If you look you will see that the trigger has three (3) stages: low, middle, and high. In slow mode you should be pumping on low speed, thereby minimizing the vapors that are created while you are pumping. All hoses at the pump have a vapor return. If you are pumping on the fast rate, some of the liquid that goes to your tank becomes vapor. Those vapors are being sucked up and back into the underground storage tank so you're getting less worth for your money.
 
 One of the most important tips is to fill up when your gas tank is HALF FULL. The reason for this is, the more gas you have in your tank the less air occupying its empty space. Gasoline evaporates faster than you can imagine. Gasoline storage tanks have an internal floating roof. This roof serves as zero clearance between the gas and the atmosphere, so it minimizes the evaporation. Unlike service stations, here where I work, every truck that we load is temperature compensated so that every gallon is actually the exact amount.
 
 Another reminder, if there is a gasoline truck pumping into the storage tanks when you stop to buy gas, DO NOT fill up--most likely the gasoline is being stirred up as the gas is being delivered, and you might pick up some of the dirt that normally settles on the bottom.
 
 Hope this will help you get the most value for your money.
 
 DO SHARE THESE TIPS WITH OTHERS!
 DISCLAIMER: This is an e-mail I received and I'm passing it on as a public service. If any aspect of this information is not accurate, I am not lying or attempting to deceive anyone, but am simply passing it on as a courtesy and a human interest story.

TIPS ON PUMPING GAS

 (Any use of the word "gas" below refers to the state/phase of matter. "Gasoline" refers to fuel.)
 
 Gasoline will vaporize less rapidly at lower temperatures, so it is true that pumping colder gasoline will minimize evaporation.
 
 Vapor will come off of the gasoline at any flow rate. The only reason I can imagine that less vapor would be produced when gasoline is moving at a slow speed is Bernoulli's principle, which would be negated within the hose. Only during the descent down the neck and into the reservoir would this have an effect. But...
 
 The "airspace" above the liquid level in the tank will reach some partial pressure of gasoline vapor based on temperature (and any gaseous impurities in the gasoline). Once this level is reached, there will be no net vaporization of gasoline unless some vapor is removed. If the "vapor return" pulls a vacuum, this would destroy this equilibrium, allowing the vapor return to stay connected in order to remove vapor for a longer period of time (due to slow gasoline pumping) would likely result in more gasoline evaporating (and subsequently being siphoned off). However, if the vapor return serves only as a non-vacuuming vent, then it is the most efficient way of allowing the tank to fill without pressurizing the tank (which you certainly don't want to do).
And now, just check the actual difference as a percentage of the total bill...

On a similar note, always take a scale to the supermarket with you, that way you can buy the box of Froot Loopz with up to 1% more in them - remember, products are not precisely uniform!!
 
 Also, industrial dumpsters out the back of groceries are often a cheap source of rotting fruit.

And remember that these 'penny pinching' tactics aren't really cost-effecient.
 For all your time and effort used to save .25 cents, you may have wasted .33 hours of your finite life. 
 A finite life that, when on your death-bed, you'll wish you'd have spent wiser rather than have wasted standing in line, sucking that last 1oz of gas out of a nozzle, jiggling that cereal box.
 
 Sorry guys, I did the math...I won't even waste 10 mins of my life standing in line if I have even something slightly more enjoyable or productive to do with my time. 
 
 Oh, I do check prices all the time and inspect the food I'm buying for quality and quantity...
 
 
 Now, if you get enjoyment out of your activities, then it probably is worth it on a subjective level.

The buying gas in the morning is a common myth that is probably not true.

I've worked at a gas station before.
 
 It's funny watching people go through all sorts of antics to save a penny.
 
 Best time to buy gas is usually the middle of the week.
 Gas prices are jacked up on weekends and holidays ('demand' is up emoticon_rolleyes )
 The morning or noon won't matter nearly as much as whether the gallon is actually a gallon (standards and measurements is important here...and yes, they're checked fairly often for accuracy).
 
 If you're an hourly worker, clock in 1 minute earlier each day. Voila you've just made more money doing that for the whole year that you did by squeezing that last drop of gas out of a hose.
 And saved yourself 4 hours of your life.
 
 If you're salaried...leave early...

 There is no way you can get on the net without an IP. How can an server met an request if they have no point of origin to return the request for? How could an website send back information on how to display an webpage when they have no address to send that information back? 
 
 As soon as you log on to an network, you are automatically provided an IP address. The reason the internet is soon changing the IP format is because so many things connect to the net, from fridges, to computer to crackberries. Everything that connects has an IP, whether its static or temporary. And given today's software, not logging IPs seems extremely out of the norm especially when it doesn't take up more then a few hundred bits.
 
 If someone sat down in an adjoining room in an apartment, as soon as they logged on they'd be provided with an IP address from that network. Universities are assigned thousands of them as they have thousands of machines using them. Similarly, routers and switches have some of their own, not many for smaller computers OR the router/switch has their own IP and then splits the data for which computer requested it. 
 
 Simply put, there is no possible way you could connect and do something on the net without an IP.

Here's one attempt to get this thread back on track. If that doesn't work, I'll just delete it.
 
 TIPS ON PUMPING GAS (Good information)
 
 
 I don't know what you guys are paying for gasoline.... but here in California we are also paying higher, up to $3.50 per gallon. But my line of work is in petroleum for about 31 years now, so here are some tricks to get more of your money's worth for every gallon..
 
 Here at the Kinder Morgan Pipeline where I work in San Jose , CA we deliver about 4 million gallons in a 24-hour period thru the pipeline. One day is diesel the next day is jet fuel, and gasoline, regular and premium grades. We have 34-storage tanks here with a total capacity of 16,800,000 gallons.
 
 Only buy or fill up your car or truck in the early morning when the ground temperature is still cold. Remember that all service stations have their storage tanks buried below ground. The colder the ground the more dense the gasoline, when it gets warmer gasoline expands, so buying in the afternoon or in the evening....your gallon is not exactly a gallon. In the petroleum business, the specific gravity and the temperature of the gasoline, diesel and jet fuel, ethanol and other petroleum products plays an important role. A 1-degree rise in temperature is a big deal for this business. But the service stations do not have temperature compensation at the pumps.
 
 When you're filling up do not squeeze the trigger of the nozzle to a fast mode. If you look you will see that the trigger has three (3) stages: low, middle, and high. In slow mode you should be pumping on low speed, thereby minimizing the vapors that are created while you are pumping. All hoses at the pump have a vapor return. If you are pumping on the fast rate, some of the liquid that goes to your tank becomes vapor. Those vapors are being sucked up and back into the underground storage tank so you're getting less worth for your money.
 
 One of the most important tips is to fill up when your gas tank is HALF FULL. The reason for this is, the more gas you have in your tank the less air occupying its empty space. Gasoline evaporates faster than you can imagine. Gasoline storage tanks have an internal floating roof. This roof serves as zero clearance between the gas and the atmosphere, so it minimizes the evaporation. Unlike service stations, here where I work, every truck that we load is temperature compensated so that every gallon is actually the exact amount.
 
 Another reminder, if there is a gasoline truck pumping into the storage tanks when you stop to buy gas, DO NOT fill up--most likely the gasoline is being stirred up as the gas is being delivered, and you might pick up some of the dirt that normally settles on the bottom.
 
 Hope this will help you get the most value for your money.
 
 DO SHARE THESE TIPS WITH OTHERS!
 DISCLAIMER: This is an e-mail I received and I'm passing it on as a public service. If any aspect of this information is not accurate, I am not lying or attempting to deceive anyone, but am simply passing it on as a courtesy and a human interest story.
